urn:contentItem:699T-9DV1-JD3N-51YN-00000-00Let's see them out fighting the bushfires2023-10-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:55:55ZLexisNexisLETTERSPg. 23Let's see them out fighting the bushfires

I hope we see Justice Richards and all the members of the Wombat Forestcare Group at the forefront of the firefight, armed with hoses, knapsacks, rake hoes and beaters when the Wombat Forest is on fire this dry summer ("Court rejects fire risk claim in Wombat row", TWT, Sept 27).

They have no concept of forest fuel-loading or fire behaviour in a forest fire. Listen to those who know and have made a lifetime study such as Associate Professor Kevin Tolhurst, and local CFA firefighters.

Like always, it will be a case of can't see the trees (what's left of them) for the smoke!

Darryl Wells, Werribee CFA member and former captain

Timber is on the ground Regarding the article on the Wombat Forest court case, Justice Melinda Richards stated that the timber was still in the coupe but was standing.

The only problem is the timber is on the ground - and the lawyers for Vic Forests should have been smart enough to pick her up on this.

The big difference, Justice Richards, is the timber has been lying on the ground for several years and drying out, whereas it was green while standing. Most of the head material would be very dry now, which makes a huge difference if there is a fire.

Justice Richards seems to have disregarded the evidence of Kevin Tolhurst, who would be the most respected fire expert in the country.

In my opinion, Justice Richards has shown what side of the fence she is on. Also Justice Richards, when one prepares a fire in the wood heater at home all the timber is laid down bunched up and crossed over so as to help with ignition. It's the same situation as the Wombat Forest only on a much larger scale.

Jim O'Dowd, Colac

Fires a sign of what's to come The past few days have reinforced CFA's messaging about the importance of preparing for fire, with significant outbreaks across East and South Gippsland impacting dozens of communities.

These early fires are a signal of what's to come this summer and it's important that households are ready and have a fire plan in place.

Last week, The Weekly Times editorial questioned the fire danger warnings issued in Victoria on a day when a different fire danger warning was in place in NSW.

There is a difference between the fuel type, fuel load and conditions on either side of the Victoria/NSW border in East Gippsland. The southern parts of NSW has large area of grassland and little to no grassland on the other side of the border in Victoria.

This is why fire danger ratings can vary between the two states, regardless of the weather conditions.

Victorians can be assured that our fire danger ratings are based on detailed and expert observations of the local conditions and specific landscape and fuel conditions and type in each municipality across the state.

As the hundreds of volunteers who have been out on the fireground over the past few days would attest, CFA brigades are well prepared to respond when called on to support their communities.

Jason Heffernan, CFA Chief Officer

Prepare for a double whammy Since 1961, when records first reported the influence of the Indian Ocean Dipole on the Australian climate, there's been nine positive (dry) events ('Double whammy brings on the heat', TWT, Sept 27).

Four have been double-whammies, with two of them in 1994 and 1997 during the crippling Millennium Drought.

The most recent, in 2015, coincided with a particularly severe El Nino. And while the 2019 El Nino may have been weak, it has the Black Summer's notch on its pistol grip. What these two have in store for us this time around is anybody's guess.

John Mosig, Kew

New Premier has previous form Victorians may have sighed in relief at the resignation of Daniel Andrews, but the track record of our new Premier is deeply concerning.

Some Victorians talk about Jacinta Allan being handed a poisoned chalice, but the reality is her fingerprints are all over it.

Just last year, she and Andrews promised a Commonwealth Games in regional Victoria. With Allan as Minister for Commonwealth Games Delivery, it was then axed, with more than $600m wasted.

She failed to champion regional Victoria then and there's little hope she will now. Peter Walsh, Victorian Nationals leader

urn:contentItem:67M4-MKT1-JD34-V03X-00000-00Uncontrolled fire growing, heading towards more towns2023-02-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:55:55ZLexisNexisUncontrolled fire growing, heading towards more townsRachael Ward

A large, fast-moving and uncontrolled grassfire north of Melbourne is growing and heading towards more towns.

The blaze started at Flowerdale, about 90 minutes from the Victorian capital, on Tuesday afternoon and is burning north towards Yea.

Waterbombing aircraft were used overnight and it's believed no homes have been impacted but the full extent of damage to fences and sheds is unknown.

The fire is more than 700 hectares in size and burning across steep, inaccessible terrain towards forested areas.

Not already a digital subscriber? Sign up for as little as $3.75 a week. Subscribers have access to download our free app today from the App Store or Google Play.

An emergency warning is in place for Flowerdale meaning it is too late for many residents to leave.

However those located between Dairy Creek Road and Handleys Road and Upper King Parrot Creek Road and Landmark Lane have been told to go before conditions get worse.

Smoke is visible across the areas and an incident control centre has been set up at Alexandra.

More than 50 CFA units are fighting the blaze with support from Forest fire Management.

An image posted to social media by the Wonga Park CFA on Tuesday night showed thick terrain glowing bright orange against the night sky.

A heatwave warning has been issued for Victoria and temperatures are expected to reach more than 30 degrees for the next three days.

Australian Associated Press

urn:contentItem:680G-6441-DY47-53JN-00000-00South Australian men caught on camera illegally cutting down red gums in Victoria's Nangeela State Forest2023-04-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:55:55ZLexisNexisSouth Australian men caught on camera illegally cutting down red gums in Victoria's Nangeela State Forest

Secret cameras have captured footage of three South Australian men stealing timber from a state forest in Victoria's south west.

Secret cameras have captured footage of three South Australian men illegally cutting down trees for firewood in a Victorian state forest.  

The men, all aged in their 20s, targeted red gums in Nangeela State Forest last September and October, according to the Victorian Conservation Regulator. 

Nangeela State Forest is located near the South West town of Casterton.

Within the forest, there are concealed cameras set up with the intention of stopping illegal firewood operations.

After being captured on the cameras monitored by the regulator, the three men admitted to cutting down red gums and taking 4 cubic metres of wood.

The men were all fined under the Forests Act 1958, and two of the offenders were given additional infringements for illegal off-road driving in breach of Land Conservation (Vehicle Control) Regulations 2013. 

Collectively, the men will be forced to pay $4,810 in fines. 

In Victoria, there are strict rules around firewood collection for domestic use.

Collection from public land is only available in designated areas listed on the Conservation Regulator website during the autumn and spring firewood collection seasons.

During this time there's a limit of 2 cubic metres per person, per day, with no more than 16 cubic metres to be collected per household within a financial year.

Only fallen timber without hollows can be taken. 

Warning as winter approaches

In a statement, Forest and Wildlife officer for the Barwon South West region Simon Donald said the fines should serve as a reminder to would-be thieves.

"Anyone thinking about taking timber from our parks and forests … will be caught and face consequences — no matter where they live," Mr Donald said. 

"Anyone illegally taking timber from public land is destroying wildlife habitat and putting our threatened native species at risk."

The warning comes as the Conservation Regulator teams up with Parks Victoria and Forest Fire Management for an anti-firewood-theft blitz dubbed "Operation Hollows".

urn:contentItem:67D2-JYJ1-JD3N-539M-00000-00Strong penalties delivered for illegal firewood collection2023-01-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:55:55ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 5Strong penalties delivered for illegal firewood collectionDAVID JOHNSTON

Two Goulburn Valley men have been convicted and fined a combined $12,500 after pleading guilty to 14 charges of illegally removing firewood from public land.

A 29-year-old Congupna man last Friday admitted to illegally cutting and taking timber multiple times between August and September 2021 from the Lower Goulburn National Park and the Loch Garry Wildlife Reserve.

He pleaded guilty to 11 charges relating to disturbing wildlife habitat, illegal firewood collection, illegal off-road driving and obstructing an authorised officer in carrying out their work.

He also had two chainsaws and a trailer destroyed as part of the penalty imposed in Shepparton Magistrates' Court.

A 37-year-old man from Shepparton, who had previously been convicted of similar offences, pleaded guilty to three charges of illegally cutting timber, disturbing wildlife habitat, and driving off-road in the Loch Garry Wildlife Reserve in September 2021.

His penalty was "steeper" due to being a repeat offender.

Conservation Regulator authorised officers detected the pair after they were captured on hidden cameras in the wildlife reserve, which were installed as part of Operation River Gum.

Operation River Gum was a joint operation between the Conservation Regulator, Forest Fire Management Victoria, and Parks Victoria to address illegal firewood removal from vulnerable ecosystems along the Murray River. The Lower Goulburn National Park and the Loch Garry Wildlife Reserve are home to sensitive environmental sanctuaries for wildlife, including threatened and rare species.

urn:contentItem:694J-5VM1-JD34-V3P9-00000-00Extreme weather threatens to kill off music festivals2023-09-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:55:55ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 4Extreme weather threatens to kill off music festivalsNell Geraets

Outdoor music festivals usually conjur images of sprawling fields peppered with tents, glitter-coated fans and lines of dubious-smelling portable toilets. Now they are as likely to be known for extreme weather of the kind that led to 70,000 Burning Man attendees being trapped on site for days last week.

Since 2013, about 41 Australian music festivals have been disrupted by bushfires, floods, lightning storms, wind or extreme heat.

Most of these disruptions occurred in the past three years, with more than 20 festivals being relocated, postponed or cancelled due to dangerous weather fuelled by climate change. The biggest of these was Splendour in the Grass in 2022, which had its first day cancelled following heavy rain and floods.

The music industry has been forced to confront vital questions: If the level of disruption continues at this rate, how much longer can outdoor music festivals continue, and what do they need to change to survive?

Though weather has always been a consideration when planning large outdoor events, Tara Medina, co-founder of Strawberry Fields - a music festival in Tocumwal, NSW that was cancelled because of La Nina-related flooding last year - says climate change has made extreme weather more frequent, severe and unpredictable.

"The weather for our first four or five events was reasonably consistent," Medina says. "The variance was: you're either going to get 20mm of rain, and it'll be colder, or it's going to be 35 degrees and hot. The extremes for us now are: it's going to be 42 degrees and a catastrophic bushfire day, or it's going to be seven metres underwater. The sweet spots are getting more and more rare."

Other popular festivals such as Yours and Owls in Wollongong, The Grass is Greener in Canberra and Geelong and Splendour In The Grass in the Northern Rivers were either partially or entirely cancelled shortly before the events were due to begin last year - a period that was supposed to mark the festival circuit's glorious comeback after its COVID-induced hiatus.

Splendour In The Grass became "Splendour In The Mud" after its first day of acts were axed following non-stop rain along the NSW coast. Now, the festival - usually the biggest in the country - is struggling to sell out and major international acts are cancelling their appearances.

This could be catastrophic for local artists who depend on festivals for exposure, as well as the Australian music scene at large, says Catherine Strong, an associate professor at RMIT who has researched the impact of climate change on music festivals.

"We're used to having this period where overseas bands come to play the festivals and then play other venues as well," Strong says. "These disruptions could threaten Australia's viability as a touring stock on a worldwide level."

It's not just Australian festivals that are facing these threats. Croatia's Fresh Island Festival was temporarily evacuated because of a forest fire in 2019 and, more recently, about 70,000 people became trapped at Nevada's Black Rock Desert after this year's Burning Man festival became a quagmire after a deluge of rain.

These kinds of worst-case scenarios not only deter festival-goers from buying tickets in advance (or from going entirely), they also contribute to already skyrocketing insurance premiums for the organisers.

So, if music festivals cannot continue as is, what could the more climate-friendly festivals of the future look like?

Green says organisers may turn to smaller-scale localised events that require less travel and create less waste, such as festivals sprawled throughout city streets and more indoor shows.

But beyond government and industry, Medina says festivals above all need audiences to commit to buying tickets early. "If we don't know whether the crowds are going to show up, then what are we fighting for? Without their trust, we don't have the confidence to invest in the future."

urn:contentItem:657C-XNV1-JD34-V33H-00000-00Firefighters warn over campfire sites2022-04-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:55:55ZLexisNexisSATURDAYPg. 13Firefighters warn over campfire sitesAlex Gretgrix

Central Victorians are being urged to follow campfire rules in state forests this Easter long weekend, with authorities handing out fines - not chocolate eggs - to those caught doing the wrong thing.

Visitor numbers to the region's parks and forests are expected to jump as the school holidays and back-to-back Easter and Anzac Day long weekends co-incide.

Golden Square Fire Brigade captain Brian Greenwood said Bendigo firefighters were preparing for a busy few weekends.

"We want people to ensure their campfires are set out properly and make sure they are following council restrictions as well as Forest Fire Management rules," he said.

"There is going to be a lot of travel across the state over the next few weekends so we want to make sure our campsites are safe for everyone.

"And if you're having a big fire, please make sure you register it so crews aren't attending planned burns for no reason."

Captain Greenwood said brigades would also be on standby to work with other emergency services if road collisions occurred.

"There's accidents that don't need to happen and are avoidable, and those incidents unfortunately can be as a result of people rushing to get home for Easter or Anzac Day," he said.

"We really just want all Victorians to arrive at their destinations safely, so take the time to arrive and ensure you're following the road rules."

Loddon Mallee Regional Forest Fire operations manager Paul Bates said while it was fantastic to see people out and about, campfire safety rules were the same across Victoria.

"Campfires must be made in purpose-built fireplaces, or trenches at least 30cm deep, with nothing flammable within three metres of your fireplace," Mr Bates said.

"All campers are responsible for keeping their campfires safe. It must be completely extinguished with water, not soil, before leaving, even if only for a short while.

"Unattended campfires can easily escape and have the potential to turn into bushfires."

Loddon Mallee Acting Regulatory Program manager Glenn Smith said Conservation Regulator and Forest Fire Management authorised officers would be patrolling across the region.

During this year's fire season, there have been 69 unattended campfires in the Loddon Mallee region since July 2021.

"Officers can issue on the spot fines of $545 to those who breach campfire rules, and a maximum penalty of up to $18,174 may apply if the matter is prosecuted in court, under the Forests Act 1958," Mr Smith said.

Unattended campfires should be reported to 136 186 with calls to triple-0 to report a bushfire. For information, visit vic.gov.au/rules-in-state-forests

urn:contentItem:693R-1KW1-F0J6-J015-00000-00Lessons from Black Summer shape training ahead of fire season2023-09-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:55:55ZLexisNexisLessons from Black Summer shape training ahead of fire seasonBeau Greenway

With the North East bracing for another severe fire season, emergency services have been sharpening up on their preparations with simulated incident responses.

More than 50 people attended an exercise at the CFA's West Wodonga incident control centre on Tuesday, September 5, based on a fast moving grass fire to the east of Wodonga, to ensure all agencies could put those skills into practice in a real life situation.

SES, CFA, Victoria Police, VicRoads and Department of Education were among the services represented.

Assistant chief fire officer Paul King said experiences from the 2019-2020 Black Summer bushfires and recent flood responses in the region helped shape the training.

"It's been well communicated that we're in for a difficult fire season. The El Nino weather conditions are returning, which means a longer, hotter, drier summer," he said.

"Whilst it's still quite wet in the landscape now, we expect that when the rain stops in spring, that fuel will dry out really quickly, especially the grass fuels.

"People say 'it's just a grass fire' but grass fires are incredibly fast, unpredictable and dangerous and can cause catastrophic damage.

"We're expecting that we'll have initially a very difficult grass fire season, just with the amount of grass caused by those wet conditions, then turning into hotter weather. That may lead into forest fire conditions later in the season.

IN THE NEWS: Robber armed with a gun takes cash from Wodonga petrol station How a stalwart became a 'legend' when the pressure was really on New public defibrillators to help save lives in North East town 'It was hard to get the words out' - Peter Hancock's emotional announcement Riverina construction company hit with $450K fine over 2020 death Vitasoy taps into the growing market for oat milk products He messaged victim of mobile phone theft in attempt to unlock device "We've had major emergencies in the last couple of years, but we haven't had a significant fire season for about three years now. Whilst we're practising managing and responding to emergencies, generally they've been floods, but fires pose different risks to us."

Mr King said response teams were "getting better every time" by running the exercises before a fire season arrives.

"The 2019-2020 fire season was devastating in the North East and we learned a lot of things from that about how we work with community, how we get access back into fire areas and how we protect people that are stuck in the fire area," he said.

"I'd like to think we get better every year, and, in fact, this exercise today is based on some of the lessons that we've learned from previous fires and the way we managed the floods.

"That's how we script these exercises, to capitalise on the lessons learned in the past."

VICSES operations manager Neil Payn relished the opportunity to be the incident controller of the scenario.

"I'm currently an endorsed level three incident controller, but I'm an SES staff member so my experience has mainly been in floods, storms and earthquakes," he said,

"This is my first opportunity working as an incident controller in a fire. I have worked in an incident management team for a fire before, but only assisting.

"These are critical to our business. We've got to exercise regularly, so it keeps people fresh and you're always learning."

The CFA can declare a fire danger period as early as October in some regions, which can remain in place for more than six months.

urn:contentItem:67JM-J2R1-DYG0-9070-00000-00FED:Victims honoured at Ash Wednesday bushfire memorials2023-02-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:55:55ZLexisNexisDOMESTIC NEWSFED:Victims honoured at Ash Wednesday bushfire memorialsMELBOURNE Feb 16

  Ceremonies will be held across Victoria and South Australia to mark the 40th anniversary of the Ash Wednesday bushfires, which killed at least 75 people.
   Families and loved ones of people killed in blazes on February 16, 1983, will pay tribute at special services on Thursday to commemorate that fateful day.


   At least 14 Country Fire Authority firefighters and three Country Fire Service volunteers died while battling blazes after more than 180 fires broke out across Victoria and parts of South Australia.
   The fires killed 47 people in Victoria, while 28 died in South Australia, where a state of disaster was declared for the first time.
   In Upper Beaconsfield, the local fire brigade will begin a five-day exhibition on Thursday to mark the 40th anniversary, while memorials will also take place in Anglesea and Aireys Inlet.
   The SA Country Fire Service has designated February 16 as Bushfire Resilience Day, with a service to be held to honour those who lost their lives in all fires, recognise the strength of those who recovered from disaster and to encourage positive actions that build greater bushfire resilience.
   In Victoria, more than 16,000 firefighters, 1000 Victoria Police officers, 500 Australian Defence Force personnel and hundreds of residents responded to the fires on Ash Wednesday, which engulfed about 210,000 hectares.
   Many fatalities were a result of firestorm conditions caused by a sudden and violent wind change, with hot winds of up to 110 km/h fanning the flames.
   While the exact cause of the fires remains largely unknown, it?s understood years of severe drought and extreme weather fuelled the blazes, according to Forest Fire Management Victoria.
   Sparks from damaged electricity power lines and suspected arson were also cited as possible causes.
